awd_titl_txt: Investigating Measurement of STEM Engagement and Advocacy in Older Adults.
awd_abstract_narration:
While prior research has explored the reasons adults seek learning opportunities, little is known about the factors that moderate older adults' desire to participate in particular learning experiences. This study will contribute to understanding strategies that engage older adults in STEM learning in informal settings. The specific informal STEM Learning (ISL) experience to be studied here involves the innovative use of a carefully structured multigenerational team engineering design challenge that incorporates the engineering design process, recognized as integrative approach to STEM. The project will develop and pilot new tools to measure the impacts of the ISL experience on older adults. The work will ultimately generate new knowledge that supports general measurement practices through the rigorous, systematic development of measures of older adult learning.
 
During the 18-month pilot study, the team will: (a) develop and test methods for measuring engagement in informal STEM learning and STEM advocacy in adults 50+ years of age; and (b) explore factors that lead to the engagement of this population in ISL and that moderate the outcome of enhanced STEM advocacy. For research purposes, engagement is being defined as focus, participation, and persistence on a task. STEM advocacy is defined as a stance toward personal actions that supports or promotes a cause or policy. The study design includes use of an intergenerational team engineering design challenge involving 48 older adults as the focal ISL activity of the research. Findings from this pilot study will inform a future large-scale study of ISL environments, including specific instructional practices and resulting outcomes, for older adult learning. Defining the construct of STEM advocacy and examining its validity as a potentially measurable outcome will better position the field to design and evaluate more effective older adult learning experiences.
 
Project results will be disseminated widely through the literature on ISL, adult education and research tool development, as well as existing practitioner networks. The project's connection with networks of lifelong learning institutes creates additional infrastructure opportunities for ISL experiences, including the broader use of intergenerational learning methods and informal STEM design challenges. This Pilot & Feasibility study is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments. This includes providing multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences, advancing innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments, and developing understandings of deeper learning by participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A team of interdisciplinary investigators from the University of California, Berkeley, conducted exploratory research on informal STEM learning among older adults through a pilot study, Investigating the Measurement of STEM Engagement and Advocacy in Older Adults. The project was a collaboration between the Osher Lifelong Learning Institute @UC Berkeley (OLLI); the Fung Fellowship for Wellness and Technology, part of the The Coleman Fung Institute for Engineering Leadership in the College of Engineering; and the Lawrence Hall of Science (LHS), the university’s public science center. 

Over the project period, the research team (a) developed methods for measuring engagement in informal STEM learning (ISL) and (b) STEM advocacy in older adults (50+) and (c) explored factors that lead to the engagement and advocacy of this population in ISL. The research team also developed an ISL experience to pilot, test, and iterate on the engagement and STEM advocacy measure. The ISL experience involved an intergenerational STEM design challenge using the engineering design process, with older adult participants recruited from OLLI, joined by undergraduates from the Fung Fellowship. 

Intellectual Merit: Our investigation of the two learning events yielded information valuable to designers of learning for older adults. In particular, we learned that older adults were highly engaged during the learning events, particularly by Intergenerational/collaborative learning, the engineering design process, and the personal relevance of the topics chosen. We also found that engagement was strongly correlated with STEM advocacy identification, and that STEM advocacy did not change as a result of a weekend learning experience. These findings suggest future opportunity for investigation to understand the type of interventions which can lead to changes in STEM advocacy of older adults. A critical step in the development of a STEM advocacy outcome measure was to identify key factors that could potentially impact older adult STEM advocacy behaviors; towards that end the research team developed an Advocacy Conceptual Model. The model depicts the relationship between predictor variables, outcome dependent variables, intention and STEM advocacy behaviors. This model allows us to explore the dimensions of STEM Advocacy in order to understand their potential relationships in influencing one’s intention or motivation to engage in STEM Advocacy. Our findings indicate that developing STEM Advocacy Identification and Efficacy may be a critical lever for encouraging STEM advocacy behaviors.

This project resulted in the development of two rigorously developed and tested scales. The resulting validated instruments are already available on the project website and have been shared at a conference presentation for the Association of Science and Technology Centers. The engagement survey can be used by informal learning providers to compare, improve, & identify approaches for engaging older adults and build an evidence base. The advocacy survey can be used to measure and understand older adults’ stance toward STEM advocacy.

Broader Impact: This project advances knowledge and understanding both within the field of informal STEM learning and across broader fields of adult education in two ways. The first is through participation and engagement. Although the reasons that adults seek learning opportunities have been explored, the factors that moderate an adult’s desire to participate and engage in a particular learning experience remain largely unexamined. The work contributes to understanding strategies that engage older adults in learning in informal settings--a declared direction of interest for research. The results of our study may also suggest specific practices that foster increased participation and engagement in all forms of adult education and better understanding of why older adults choose to participate in informal learning. The second is measuring critical outcomes: This work contributes to ISL’s definition and measurement of the impacts of older adult STEM learning. Our work to define the construct of STEM advocacy and to explore its validity as a potentially measurable outcome better positions the field to design effective adult learning experiences and to assess for whom and under which conditions these experiences best support STEM learning. The work also generated new knowledge that supports general measurement practices through the systematic development of measures of older adult learning.

The study results have the potential to increase ISL opportunities for an expanding audience, older adults, through findings that will guide the optimal structure of the experiences to increase participation and engagement. The use of a lifelong learning institute (LLLI) as the informal learning environment creates additional infrastructure opportunities for providing ISL experiences for older adults. Additionally, the use of intergenerational learning methods involving the “skipped generations” of older adults (50+) and undergraduate students in shared responsibility for the design challenge could lead to the introduction of new collaborations between LLLI informal learning organizations and engineering programs in their host/sponsoring colleges/universities.
